q: Mark is working on VueJS on events. He wants to emit an event from the custom component to the parent which he created. He decided to use the $emit function. What are the arguments this emit function accepts?

Mark is using Events in VueJS. He wants to listen directly to a native event on the root element of a custom component he created. Now in this case, which directive can he use?

John is working on Events in VueJS. He is developing a single-page application where he used the v-model on a component. As v-model uses value as the prop and input as the event. Here is the code snippet.

Vue.component('hacker-checkbox', {
  props: {
    checked: Boolean
  },
  template: `
    <input
      type="checkbox"
      v-bind:checked="checked"
      v-on:change="$emit('change', $event.target.checked)"
    >
  `
})

But for some input types such as checkboxes and radio buttons he wants to use the value attribute for a different purpose in the backend. What should John do to avoid this conflict?

a.option: Sub-divding the component into further components

q: Mark is working on Events using VueJS. He wrote a code logic that contains many event handlers. Since this will make the process complex as keeping the value of the v-on attribute isn’t feasible. So what should Ben do to overcome the drawback?

a.option: adding name of a method as input

q:
Lisa is working with Events in VueJS. She wants to add a dynamic counter button and she wrote the following html code.

<div id="hacker">
  <h1>+1 this post</h1>
  <button v-on:click="counter += 1">+1</button>
  <p>You have +1 the post {{ counter }} times.</p>
</div>

 What should Lisa add for the v-on directive Vue code to make the given code work?

Options

1.

var hacker = Vue.Create({
  el: '#hacker',
  data: {
    counter: 0
  }
})

2.

var hacker = new Vue({
  el: '#hacker',
  data: {
    counter: 0
  }
})

 

3.

var hacker = Vue.Create({
  el: '#hacker',
  data: {
    counter: 0
  }
  onclick: {
    counter++
  }
})

4.

var hacker = new Vue({
  el: '#hacker',
  data: {
    counter: 0
  }
  onclick: {
    counter++
  }
})

You have created an app in Angular. In this app, you have used various mouse events to display various functions. Which of the following is NOT a mouse event?

You want to count the number of times a mouse has been moved over a certain text 'Mouse over me'. You have written the code such that below the text is shown the number of times the mouse has been moved over the text. Select from the code sections given in options that provide the above functionality.

Options

  1. <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="PersonCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="count = count + 1">Mouse Over Me!</h1>

<h2>{{ count }}</h2>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
 $scope.count = 0;
});
</script> 

</body>
</html>
  2. <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="count = count + 1">Mouse Over Me!</h1>

<h2>{{ countOverMe }}</h2>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
 $scope.count = 0;
});
</script> 

</body>
</html>

     

  3. <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="count = count + 1">Mouse Over Me!</h1>

<h2>{{ count }}</h2>

</div>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
 $scope.count = 0;
});
</body> 
</html>

     

  4. <!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/angularjs/1.6.9/angular.min.js"></script>
<body>

<div ng-app="myApp" ng-controller="myCtrl">

<h1 ng-mousemove="count = count + 1">Mouse Over Me!</h1>

<h2>{{ count }}</h2>

</div>
<script>
var app = angular.module('myApp', []);
app.controller('myCtrl', function($scope) {
 $scope.count = 0;
});
</script> 

</body>
</html>

In C# you are working on Events, you have a code given below which defines an event hackCompleted. Now, which of the following statements is correct about the EventArgs.Empty parameter passed in the OnhackCompleted() method in the code snippet given below?

Code

class Hackerearth
{
    public static void Main()
    {
        hackProcess h = new hackProcess();
        h.hackCompleted += h_hackCompleted;
        h.hackStart();
    }
    public static void h_hackCompleted(object sender, EventArgs e)
    { 
        Console.WriteLine("hack completed") 
    }
}
public class hackProcess 
{
    public event EventHandler hackCompleted; 

    public void hackStart()
    {
        Console.WriteLine("Hacking started");
        OnhackCompleted(EventArgs.Empty);
    }
    
    protected virtual void OnhackCompleted(EventArgs e)
    { 
        ProcessCompleted?.Invoke(this, e); 
    }
}

 

Statements

  1. It is passed to event handlers that are associated with events that have data and it does not notify subscribers about the completion of the process.


     

  2. It is passed to event handlers that are associated with events that do not have data and it notifies subscribers about the completion of the process.


     

  3. It is passed to event handlers that are associated with events that have data and it notifies subscribers about the completion of the process.


     

  4. It is passed to event handlers that are associated with events that do not have data and it does not notify subscribers about the completion of the process.

In C#, you are working on Events. Consider the C# code snippet given below that shows how to work with events. The code contains a class named Hackerearth that has an event named ReachedThreshold. Now, which of the following statements is correct about this code snippet?

Code

using System;
namespace hack_event
{
    class Hackerearth_Event
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            Hackerearth c = new Hackerearth(new Random().Next(10));
            c.ReachedThreshold += c_ReachedThreshold;
            
            Console.WriteLine("press the 'c' key from the keyboard to increase total");
            while (Console.ReadKey(true).KeyChar == 'c')
            {
                Console.WriteLine("Incrementing by 1");
                c.Add(1);
                
            }
            
        }
        static void c_ReachedThreshold(object sender, EventArgs e)
        {
            Console.WriteLine("Reached the threshold already.");
            Environment.Exit(0);
            
        }
        
    }
    class Hackerearth
    {
        private int threshold;
        private int total;
        public Hackerearth(int passedThreshold)
        { 
            threshold = passedThreshold; 
            
        }
        public void Add(int x)
        {
            total += x;
            if (total >= threshold)
            { 
                OnReachingTheThreshold(EventArgs.Empty); 
                
            }
            
        }
        protected virtual void OnReachingTheThreshold(EventArgs e)
        {
            EventHandler handler = ReachedThreshold;
            if (handler != null)
            { 
                handler(this, e); 
                
            }
            
        }
        public event EventHandler ReachedThreshold;
        
    }
}

 

Statements

  1. The code depicts the process to raise and consume an event in the absence of data.
     
  2. When a Hackerearth value equals or exceeds a threshold value, the event is raised.

In C# you are working on Events and Delegates, you have a code given below which defines an event hackProcessCompleted. Now, which of the following statements is correct about this code?

Code

public delegate void hack(); 
 
public class hackProcess
{
    public event hackProcessCompleted; 
    public void hackStart()
    {
        Console.WriteLine("hacking initiated");
 
        OnhackCompleted();
    }
    protected virtual void OnhackCompleted() 
    { 
        hackProcessCompleted?.Invoke();  
        
    }
}

 

Statements

  1. A derived class should always call the On(Name of the event) method of the base class to ensure that registered delegates receive the event.


     

  2. On(name of the event)methods should be marked as Protected and Virtual.

            {

            h(); 
        }

}

    Hi Hackerearth

What will be the output of the C# code given below?

Code

using System;
namespace Delegates 
{ 
    public class hack
    { 
        public static void hack1() 
        { 
            Console.WriteLine("Hi"); 
            throw new Exception("Caught an error"); 
        } 
        public static void hack2() 
        { 
            Console.WriteLine("Hello"); 
        } 
        
    } 
    class Hackerearth 
    { 
        delegate void hackOp(); 
        static void Main(string[] args) 
        {
            hackOp h = hack.hack1; 
            h += hack.hack2; 
            Delegate[] hc = h.GetInvocationList(); 
            foreach (hackOp c in hc) 
            { 
                try 
                { 
                    c(); 
                    
                } 
                catch (Exception) 
                { 
                    Console.WriteLine("Error"); 
                    
                } 
                
            } 
        } 
        
    } 
    
}



Output

  1. Error
Hello


     

  2. Hi
Error
Hello


     

  3. Error
Hi


     

  4. Hi
Hello
Error

In C#, you are working on Events and you are implementing Interface Events. In which of the following scenarios will the code snippet given below be beneficial?

Code:

namespace WrapTwoInterfaceEvents
{
    using System;
    public interface IDrawingObject
    {
        event EventHandler OnDraw;
        
    }
    public class Shape : IDrawingObject, IShape
    {
        event EventHandler PreDrawEvent;
        object objectLock = new Object();
        
        #region IDrawingObjectOnDraw
        
        event EventHandler IDrawingObject.OnDraw
        {
            add
            {
                lock (objectLock)
                {
                    PreDrawEvent += value;
                    
                }
                
            }
            remove
            {
                lock (objectLock)
                {
                    PreDrawEvent -= value;
                    
                }
                
            }
            
        }
        #endregion
        
        public void Draw()
        {
            PreDrawEvent?.Invoke(this, EventArgs.Empty);
            Console.WriteLine("Drawing a shape.");
            
        }
}




 

  1. This can be used in situations where a class inherits from two or more interfaces and each interface has an event with the same name.


     

  2. This can be used in if the events should be raised at different times according to the interface specifications.

In C# you are working on Events and Delegates and you have a code given below which defines an event hc and a delegate EventHandler. Now, which of the following syntaxes can be used in place of YYY to complete the code snippet?

Code

using System; 
namespace Delegates 
{ 
    public delegate void EventHandler(string h);
    
    class Hackerearth
    { 
        public static void HackEvent(string hk) 
        { 
            Console.WriteLine("hi"); 
            
        } 
        static void Main(string[] args) 
        { 
            hack h1= new hack(); 
            h1.Action("bye"); 
            YYY            
        } 
        
    }
    
    public class hack
    { 
        public event EventHandler hc; 
        public void Action(string h) 
        { 
            if (hc!= null) 
            { 
                hc(h); 
                Console.WriteLine(h); 
                
            } 
            else 
            { 
                Console.WriteLine("hello"); 
                
            } 
            
        } 
        
    } 
  
}

 

 

Syntaxes

  1. h1.hc = new EventHandler(HackEvent);


     

  2. new EventHandler(HackEvent);


     

  3. h1.hc+= new EventHandler(HackEvent);


     

  4. h1.hc = new CatchEvent;

What is the output of the C# code snippet given below?

Code:

using System;
public class DelegateEvent
{
    public delegate void HandlerEventDelegate();
    public static double original_amount= 4533.47;
    public static void AmountDeposit()
    { 
        Console.WriteLine("Current Bank Balance: "+original_amount); 
        
    }
    public static void RewardBonus()
    {
        if(original_amount>= 12000)
        {
            double amountBonus = 1200;
            Console.WriteLine("Bonus Applied and now the total Bank Balance: "+(original_amount+amountBonus ));
            
        } 
        else
        { 
            Console.WriteLine("Bonus Inapplicable"); 
            
        }
        
    }
    public static event HandlerEventDelegate obj;
    public static void Main(string[] args)
    {
        obj+= new HandlerEventDelegate (AmountDeposit);
        obj+= new HandlerEventDelegate (RewardBonus);
        obj.Invoke();
        
    }
 }



Output:

  1. Current Bank Balance: 4533.00

Bonus Applied and now the total Bank Balance: 12000


     

  2. Current Bank Balance: 4533.47

Bonus Applied and now the total Bank Balance: 12200


     

  3. Current Bank Balance: 4533

Bonus Applied and now the total Bank Balance: 12200


     

  4. Current Bank Balance: 4533.47

Bonus Inapplicable
